perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall automatically terminate at and as of (the first to occur of): (a) 12:00 midnight, New York City time,  on the 30th day after the Effective Date (if Purchaser has not commenced the Offer, with the unanimous consent of the Sponsors, by then); (b) the  expiration of the Offer (if the Offer is not consummated pursuant to the terms of the Offer), subject to any extension or subsequent offering period;  and (c) the expiration of the Interim Period (if the Offer is consummated pursuant to the terms of the Offer), in any case, unless sooner terminated  by unanimous written consent of the Participating Sponsors; provided, however, that any liability for failure to comply with this Agreement shall  survive any such termination. Notwithstanding the foregoing, each Section hereof (other than Sections 1 through 6 (inclusive) hereof) shall  survive indefinitely following the termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall automatically terminate at and as of (the first to occur of): (a) 12:00 midnight, New York City time, on the 10th day after the Effective Date (if Purchaser has not commenced the Offer, with the unanimous consent of the Sponsors, by then); (b) the expiration of the Offer (if the Offer is not consummated pursuant to the terms of the Offer), subject to any extension or subsequent offering period; and (c) the expiration of the Interim Period (if the Offer is consummated pursuant to the terms of the Offer), in any case, unless sooner terminated by unanimous written consent of the Participating Sponsors; provided, however, that any liability for failure to comply with this Agreement shall survive any such termination. Notwithstanding the foregoing, each Section hereof (other than Sections 1 through 6 (inclusive) hereof) shall survive indefinitely following the termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the period before automatic termination from 30 days to 10 days if the offer hasn't commenced could be considered unreasonably short, depending on the complexity and regulatory requirements of the tender offer. This creates an inconsistency because a reasonable timeframe is generally expected for commencing such a significant financial undertaking, and 10 days might not be sufficient for compliance with securities regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates implied duties of good faith and fair dealing under New York law, if 10 days is deemed an unreasonably short time to commence the offer, undermining the agreement's purpose.

perturbation.original_text: Purchaser shall (and each Sponsor shall cause each Unit owned by such Sponsor, if any, to be voted to cause  Purchaser to) authorize, issue, sell, or exchange, as applicable, Units to Participating Sponsors pro rata (based on the Commitments of Participating  Sponsors) and otherwise in accordance with the Equity Commitment Letters and this Agreement; provided, however, that each Unit of any class or  series shall be issued at the same price(s) and in the same proportion(s) as all other Units of such class or series.
perturbation.changed_text: Purchaser shall (and each Sponsor shall cause each Unit owned by such Sponsor, if any, to be voted to cause Purchaser to) authorize, issue, sell, or exchange, as applicable, Units to Participating Sponsors at a price determined solely by the Purchaser, regardless of the Commitments of Participating Sponsors, and not necessarily in accordance with the Equity Commitment Letters and this Agreement; provided, however, that Units may be issued at varying prices and proportions at the Purchaser's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: This modification allows the Purchaser to issue units at varying prices and proportions, which directly contradicts the original clause stating they must be issued at the same price and in the same proportion. This change introduces potential breaches of fiduciary duty and contractual fairness, particularly if some sponsors are disadvantaged in unit pricing or allocation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates fiduciary duties owed to minority shareholders and contractual obligations under Delaware law, especially if the Purchaser's discretion is used to unfairly dilute the value of some sponsors' investments.

perturbation.original_text: To the fullest extent permitted by law, each Sponsor shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless each other Sponsor  and any of its affiliates or any direct or indirect partner, member, shareholder, employee, director, officer or agent of such Sponsor or any of its  affiliates from and against any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, judgments, awards, settlements, demands, offsets, and expenses  (including interest, penalties, court costs, arbitration costs and fees, witness fees and reasonable fees and expenses of outside attorneys,  investigators, expert witnesses, accountants and other professionals) arising out of or relating to any material breach or inaccuracy of the  representations, warranties or covenants of such Sponsor contained herein.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Sponsor shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless each other Sponsor only for losses directly caused by intentional fraud, proven with clear and convincing evidence, and only up to a maximum of $10,000, excluding any consequential damages or legal fees.
perturbation.explanation: This drastically limits the scope of indemnification. The original clause provides broad indemnification 'to the fullest extent permitted by law' for any material breach. The modified clause restricts it to intentional fraud proven with 'clear and convincing evidence,' a high legal standard, caps the amount at $10,000, and excludes consequential damages and legal fees. This change creates significant inconsistencies as it severely reduces the protections afforded to sponsors and may violate implied duties of good faith if it undermines the purpose of the indemnification clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially unenforceable as unconscionable under New York law if the limitation on liability is deemed too restrictive and unfairly favors one party over another, or if it violates public policy regarding fraud.
